results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

In this film, Billy travels to the Russian cities of Leningrad and Moscow.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:04:00 some quick views the ‘Latvia’ passenger ship in sail
00:00:20:00 scenes in a European city including some construction sites
00:00:52:00 the domes of the St Petersburg Cathedral (also called Church of the resurrection of Christ or Church of the Saviour on Spilled Blood) in St Petersburg, Russia
00:02:21:00 looking at the St Petersburg Cathedral framed in the distance through snowy tree branches
00:02:40:00 Red Square in Moscow, Russia
00:03:39:00 St Basil’s Cathedral in Moscow, Russia
00:04:27:00 snow on people and traffic in Moscow
00:05:17:00 pedestrians and cars on the streets of Moscow
00:06:50:00 cars driving alongside a river in Moscow
00:07:05:00 a crowd watches a military parade of personal and armoured vehicles
00:09:03:00 snowy streets
00:09:49:00 airplane exhibition
00:10:27:00 people tobogganing in the snow amongst some trees
00:11:00:00 people take to their skis in a snowy forest

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 30]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

In this film, Wallace focuses on Australian birdlife, particularly waterbirds filmed from a small boat among lily pads and overhanging trees on still waterways located in the Northern Territory of Australia.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’ (dramatically placed over a crocodile with jaws raised and open), ‘Wild Paradise’
00:00:18:00 a close-up of bougainvillea, some men in shorts look nervously at the camera and cormorants (water birds) stand among water lilies and reeds
00:00:49:00 the men take to the water in a small fishing boat with outboard motor and pass by some waterbirds including cormorants, a large pelican, white egrets
00:02:01:00 the boat passes a flock of magpie geese followed by more pelicans, storks and black ibis
00:02:38:00 a white bellied sea eagle perched in a tree
00:02:48:00 some spoonbill and other water birds
00:04:05:00 a large black necked stork takes off in flight
00:04:13:00 a pelican stands with a chick close by
00:04:45:00 views around the river and wetlands
00:05:26:00 a lone magpie goose stands at the water and a few white egrets in flight
00:06:10:00 a darter water bird perched in a tree
00:06:23:00 an eagle on the very top of a tree
00:06:43:00 a large pelican sitting among lily pads
00:06:48:00 the sightseers on their boat
00:08:19:00 campsite alongside the river
00:09:44:00 water buffalo, dirt roads and flowering trees
00:10:50:00 irrigation in a banana tree plantation
00:11:09:00 a tourist bus on a dusty road
00:11:46:00 what appears to be an old ‘fan boat’ for skimming over swamps and wetlands
00:12:23:00 a black and white heron looking for dinner in the water
00:14:47:00 vehicles on a road leading into a town
00:15:11:00 driving into Darwin
00:15:49:00 the ‘Paspalis Centrepoint’ building in Darwin
00:15:54:00 a banner across the road for a concert featuring ‘Australian Crawl’ and ‘John Farnham’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 29]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is about a trip around North Queensland to locations such as Townsville and National Parks. Wallace films the wonderful brolga water birds of the title but also captures the dramatic Wallaman Falls in Girringun Park, which is Australia’s highest permanent single drop waterfall, and the Little Crystal Creek Bridge on Mount Spec Rd in Paluma Range National Park. The bridge and Mt Spec Road are of particular interest as both are listed heritage sites on the Queensland Heritage Register and were constructed during the Great Depression in the 1930s using mostly unskilled labour and with the application of ‘Unemployment Relief Scheme’ funds. Mt Spec Road remains substantially intact throughout the 18km of its length and demonstrates an extensive and now uncommon use of concrete arch culverts, dry stone walling and stone-paved gutters. Also, the very picturesque bridge is the only identified concrete arch bridge dressed with stone remaining in service in Queensland.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Where Brolgas Dance’, ‘Filmed by WHC’
00:00:27:00 the ‘Air Cloud’ tour boat moored at a pier
00:00:32:00 looking out from the pier over a lake or river followed by boats sitting on sand and mud when the tide is out and remains of old jettys
00:01:03:00 views of boats moored at jettys and piers
00:02:09:00 sunflowers in the foreground of mountains
00:02:27:00 the ‘Burdekin Bridge’ rail and car bridge in Queensland
00:03:38:00 sugar cane, wetlands and lily pads and roaming cattle
00:04:13:00 a large spider web in the wetlands complete with black spider in the middle
00:04:30:00 driving through Townsville in Queensland, and past the ‘T&G Building’
00:06:13:00 views of brolgas standing in grass and flying overhead
00:07:52:00 signs for ‘Mt Spec National Park’ and ‘Little Crystal Creek’
00:07:59:00 views of the Little Crystal Creek Bridge and the creek itself with its lovely rocky banks
00:08:24:00 a roadside picnic and exploring under the bridge
00:08:54:00 sign for ‘McClelland Bridge’ followed by scenic views of mountains and waterways
00:10:06:00 driving through the rainforest
00:10:48:00 views of the dramatic Wallaman Falls
00:11:01:00 sign for the Falls with facts and information for campers
00:11:34:00 sightseers at a lookout
00:12:03:00 a small modest road bridge
00:12:16:00 title ‘The End’

results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 12]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

This film contains scenes of Billy’s travels on the steamship Southern Cross, in 1960 which travelled between Australia and Europe. It is a little difficult to locate exactly where Billy visits but we can definitely see scenes of England, the Netherlands and Greece. The SS Southern Cross was a modern passenger ship built in 1955 to an innovative design which catered specifically for the tourist trade, starting a trend of ‘aft-engined’ ships, leaving more space for passengers and their needs. The Southern Cross was also the first major liner to have no cargo space, other than for ship’s stores and passenger luggage.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 views of a shoreline and sea
00:01:14:00 a large ship or ferry being loaded at the dock
00:01:48:00 a large and busy tugboat
00:01:50:00 passengers playing tennis on the deck of a ship
00:02:30:00 South Africa Airways airplane on the tarmac
00:03:15:00 a large fountain in a town setting
00:03:49:00 mountain views followed by a picturesque river flowing through hills
00:04:23:00 passengers travelling from a ship, in what appears to be a large lifeboat, to shore
00:04:51:00 views of a large military memorial in a public square setting.
00:04:58:00 dancers in traditional costume give an exhibition of Greek folk dancing to passengers on board a ship.
00:06:19:00 town houses and buildings overlooking houseboats moored on the banks of a canal, with a sign for Grachten (canal)
00:06:58:00 tramcar in a town
00:07:14:00 a large and crowded beach
00:07:36:00 street scenes
00:08:15:00 keen swimmers in a canal or river
00:08:24:00 a glimpse of a windmill
00:08:50:00 boats, ferries and yachts in a bay
00:09:30:00 a passenger ship arrives at a dock
00:10:54:00 scenes of lovely hills and farmlands, thatched cottages and beaches
00:12:15:00 a ‘Punch and Judy’ tent indicates that Billy is in England
00:14:50:00 a plane is filmed overhead
00:15:15:00 a Greek ‘Evezone’ presidential guard dressed in traditional costume
00:16:16:00 a spectacular view of mountain seen at the end of a street, behind shops and buildings, probably in Greece

description_for_label:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

This film contains scenes of Billy’s travels on the steamship Southern Cross, in 1960 which travelled between Australia and Europe. It is a little difficult to locate exactly where Billy visits but we can definitely see scenes of England, the Netherlands and Greece. The SS Southern Cross was a modern passenger ship built in 1955 to an innovative design which catered specifically for the tourist trade, starting a trend of ‘aft-engined’ ships, leaving more space for passengers and their needs. The Southern Cross was also the first major liner to have no cargo space, other than for ship’s stores and passenger luggage.

results.title: [Remix: Sunnies]
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, ACMI Collections and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Worn at the beach or on a bush walk, or simply as a style statement, this playful short film is a tribute to the fashion accessory, and sun-smart, sun glasses. Set to a boss nova soundtrack, this short work is a tribute to ‘shades’, showing people wearing sun glasses cut from home movies and short works in the ACMI Collection. Featured are some of fashion’s best styles of eye wear from the 1940s to the 1970s.

ACMI gratefully acknowledge the following donors and creators in the compilation of this work: Tasmanian Archive and Heritage Office; Elenor Peach; Barry Parsons; The Gadsden Family and Neville Daley.

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film captures a major event in the lives of the Nixon family – daughter Karen’s wedding. The fashion on the day is a wonderful example of the late 1980s and the bridesmaids wear Karen’s favourite colour, red. Karen’s new family, the Corrys, are in the film having visited from the UK.

Of interest in this film, when Karen arrives at the church there are many onlookers who are there but are not guests. At this period of time it was still customary, particularly in country areas, for members of the community to come along to watch the bridal party arrive and leave the church.

Later we see Karen preparing to leave for overseas possibly to Indonesia as we view a Garuda airplane from what appears to be the Observation Deck at Tullamarine Airport, Melbourne, when it was still open.

This film also contains scenes of a new kitten in the family, inside the house and in the yard chasing a rope hanging from the clothes line.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 Karen in a 1980s style wedding dress and her bridesmaids dressed in red, are relaxed for the camera in the family lounge room and outside on the terrace
00:01:15:00 the bridal party arrives at the church among a group of interested onlookers
00:01:24:00 father Les and daughter Karen pose for the camera alongside the bridal car
00:01:35:00 the bride and groom exchange rings inside the church (quite dark and grainy)
00:02:00:00 the bridal party pose for the camera, the men showing off some wonderful 1980s moustaches
00:02:42:00 the Nixon parents and the Corry parents gather with the bride and groom for a group photo
00:03:20:00 a family gathering in the backyard of the Geelong family home after the wedding
00:03:39:00 Dorothy, mother of the bride and always stylish, wearing a good example of a 1980s sundress in pink with black dots
00:04:16:00 having fun: a member of the family poses in a ‘Foster’s Lager’ singlet whilst drinking a ‘Foster’s Lager’ before then posing with a ‘beer gut’ shape for the camera
00:06:39:00 another family wedding where Karen is an attendant
00:07:22:00 a sign outside the church which states, ‘Do Not Drop Confetti’
00:09:35:00 Karen and her husband relaxed in front of the camera in the church grounds
00:12:40:00 a family gathering in the backyard
00:13:42:00 Karen packing for travel in front of a Christmas tree where a kitten is playing
00:14:23:00 a set Christmas table and then the family seated at the table except for Les who is filming
00:14:55:00 Karen checking in at the airport
00:15:54:00 airplanes on the tarmac being filmed from the rooftop Observation Deck at Melbourne Airport
00:19:50:00 after many scenes of playing, we see an exhausted kitten asleep in a cardboard box

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film begins with Dorothy, Karen and Stuart relaxing around the family Christmas tree, 1984 and moves onto family activities in the backyard. There are two extended family weddings and some wonderful fashion from the early 1980s.

The highlight of the film is Karen’s 21st birthday where we see the traditional table for the presents to be displayed before Karen proudly poses for the camera in front of her new car.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 Dorothy, Karen and Stuart chatting, whilst seated around their Christmas tree at home
00:00:23:00 Karen in some fantastic embroidered trousers with a boyfriend, Dorothy and Stuart in the garden at home
00:00:35:00 family barbeque in the backyard
00:00:53:00 classic 1970s and 1980s style glassware
00:02:33:00 ‘totem’ tennis being played in the backyard
00:02:50:00 Stuart and a friend or cousin being rallied to pose for the camera
00:04:23:00 large family gathering in a park including a lovely group shot of grandchildren and greatgrandchildren with a grandparent
00:06:39:00 Stuart poses with a sports trophy
00:07:32:00 extended family wedding where Karen is a bridesmaid
00:08:30:00 Karen’s 21st birthday scenes where she and her brother wear matching red and white outfits and Dorothy is in a very smart dress that matches the theme
00:08:51 Karen shows off her birthday presents that are displayed on a table set up for the purpose
00:09:05:00 Karen and her new car

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film features tennis tournaments in Geelong, Ballarat and Shepparton, as well as horse riding at a family farm and attending the extended family weddings in Bellbrae and Geelong. A highlight is Karen’s 13th birthday.

Selected highights list:
00:00:38:00 Karen and Stuart in their uniforms, for Bells Park Primary School
00:02:20:00 the family enjoying their garden
00:02:35:00 birthday cake in the backyard, probably for Karen’s 13th birthday
00:03:22:00 Karen and other young tennis players
00:04:30:00 a group of cyclists ride up a hill
00:05:35:00 camping and tennis
00:06:02:00 a group of older women of the family smile for the camera
00:07:05:00 Dorothy and Stuart smile at the camera
00:07:40:00 water skiing on a river seen in the background, and swimmers in a swimming pool
00:08:19:00 a boy in the extended family poses in his pyjamas near a classic ‘Hills Hoist’ washing line at a camping and caravan park
00:08:50:00 Dorothy playing tennis
00:11:10:00 Stuart on a ‘Dragster’ bicycle
00:12:55:00 Stuart paints the family home terrace rail, followed by Les painting the house
00:13:28:00 Stuart proudly shows his new watch to the camera
00:14:33:00 horse riding
00:19:00:00 family wedding featuring a fabulous example of a 1970s dress
00:19:23:00 a member of the bridal party sporting fabulous 1970s ‘sideburns’
00:22:20:00 a row of moustaches in the bridal party

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film is about family life in Geelong in the 1970s. Children Karen and Stuart have a ride on a motorbike, visits to the beach, to the ‘Bell Brae’ farm and to the snow, Karen’s 9th birthday party (filmed inside so quite dark), preparing for school, sports days and an extended family wedding. There are some great examples of 1970s fashion, particularly of the home made style.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:10:00 giving the children a ride on a motorcycle
00:00:20:00 family gathering sitting on the sand at the beach, eating ice creams
00:03:43:00 children surfing the waves
00:05:37:00 Karen’s nineth birthday party celebrations
00:05:55:00 the children riding their bikes around the house and the street, confident Karen waves to the camera
00:07:20:00 mother and daughter in the garden, Karen wearing ‘hotpants’ which were very popular in the 1970s
00:07:23:00 Karen poses for the camera in her ‘Brownies’ uniform
00:08:04:00 the grandparents of the family
00:08:58:00 Karen and Stuart ready for school
00:09:03:00 fishing off a pier
00:09:55:00 spectacular early 1970s hairstyles in preparation for one of the many family weddings
00:11:54:00 a family wedding in 1970s style
00:12:15:00 an extended family gathering
00:15:17:00 a visit to play in what might be sudden fall of snow
00:16:36:00 dad is wearing a 1970s ‘groovy’ outfit while posing with Karen and Stuart in the garden
00:17:07:00 Karen and companions do a ‘physical education’ display for the camera
00:17:57:00 Karen and Stuart pose with a blowup Santa in the garden
00:18:54:00 jet skiing at the beach
